docs.title: Admin Client
docs.description: The admin client hosts all the cluster operations, such as: createTopics, createPartitions, etc.

docs.title: Client Configuration
docs.description: The client must be configured with at least one broker. The brokers on the list are considered seed brokers and are only used to bootstrap the client and load initial metadata.

docs.title: Consumer
docs.description: The following example assumes that you are using the local Kafka configuration described in Running Kafka in Development.

docs.title: Consuming Messages
docs.description: Consumer groups allow a group of machines or processes to coordinate access to a list of topics, distributing the load among the consumers. When a consumer fails the load is automatically distributed to other members of the group. Consumer groups must have unique group ids within the cluster, from a kafka broker perspective.

docs.title: Contributing
docs.description: KafkaJS is an open-source project where development takes place in the open on GitHub. Although the project is maintained by a small group of dedicated volunteers, we are grateful to the community for bug fixes, feature development and other contributions.

docs.title: Custom Logger
docs.description: The logger is customized using log creators. A log creator is a function which receives a log level and returns a log function. The log function receives namespace, level, label, and log.

docs.title: Development Environment
docs.description: When developing KafkaJS, we run a Kafka cluster in a similar way to what is described in Running Kafka in Development, using docker and docker-compose. Before you proceed, make sure that you have both docker and docker-compose available.

docs.description: When developing KafkaJS, these are some useful resources:

docs.description: Is KafkaJS used in production?

docs.description: Some operations are instrumented using EventEmitter. To receive the events use the method consumer.on(), producer.on() and admin.on(), example:

docs.title: A Brief Intro to Kafka
docs.description: Kafka is a messaging system that safely moves data between systems. Depending on how each component is

docs.title: Pre-releases
docs.description: Stable KafkaJS versions can take a while to be released. Release candidates are usually deployed in production for at least a week before general availability. We do this to make sure that all releases are stable, and we trust our services to verify most production use-cases. Although this process guarantees some quality, it can be too slow or unpredictable. Some versions go out faster than others, and it can be frustrating if you need a particular feature that has not been included in a stable release yet.

docs.title: Producer
docs.description: The following example assumes that you are using the local Kafka configuration described in Running Kafka in Development.

docs.description: To publish messages to Kafka you have to create a producer. Simply call the producer function of the client to create it:

docs.description: The retry mechanism uses a randomization function that grows exponentially. This formula and how the default values affect it is best described by the example below:

docs.title: Running Kafka in Development
docs.description: The following configuration will be used in the examples listed here. For more complete and up-to-date documentation, see wurstmeister/kafka-docker.

docs.title: Testing
docs.description: We rely on a suite of largely integration tests, using jest as a test runner.

docs.title: Transactions
docs.description: KafkaJS provides a a simple interface to support Kafka transactions.
